sections.heading: Reason for Referral
sections.content: Ms. Jane Doe is being referred to the Endocrinology Clinic for further evaluation and management of persistently elevated fasting blood glucose levels and newly diagnosed hypothyroidism.

sections.heading: History of Present Illness
sections.content: Ms. Doe reports a six-month history of increased fatigue, unintentional weight gain of approximately 7 kg, and intermittent headaches. She has also noticed increased thirst and frequent urination over the past two months. There is no history of visual changes, chest pain, or palpitations. Her past medical history is notable for mild hypertension, well controlled on lisinopril.

sections.heading: Relevant Medical History
sections.content: No previous history of diabetes mellitus. Family history is significant for type 2 diabetes in her mother and thyroid disease in her maternal aunt. No known drug allergies. Current medications include lisinopril 10 mg daily and a daily multivitamin.

sections.heading: Examination and Investigations
sections.content: On examination, Ms. Doe is alert and oriented, BMI is 31.2 kg/m2. Blood pressure is 128/82 mmHg. Recent laboratory investigations revealed fasting blood glucose of 146 mg/dL, HbA1c of 7.2%, and TSH of 8.5 mIU/L with low free T4. Lipid profile shows mild hypercholesterolemia.

sections.heading: Assessment
sections.content: Ms. Doe appears to have newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus and primary hypothyroidism. Her symptoms and laboratory results are consistent with these diagnoses.

sections.heading: Plan
sections.content: Referral to Endocrinology is requested for further evaluation and initiation of appropriate management for both diabetes and hypothyroidism. In the interim, Ms. Doe has been advised on dietary modifications, exercise, and to monitor her blood glucose at home. Consideration of starting metformin and levothyroxine is recommended pending specialist input.
